extractions.extraction_text: Structured data is you know exactly the meaning about the row and column.

attributes.definition: Data organized in a predictable structure, often in rows and columns, where the meaning of each element is clear.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that is neatly organized, like in a spreadsheet, where you know what each piece of information represents.

extractions.extraction_text: Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

attributes.definition: Complex and varied data, typically from human-generated content like images, text, and videos, which can be difficult to interpret.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that doesn't have a predefined format, like photos, videos, or free-form text, making it harder to process automatically.

extractions.extraction_text: Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Human-generated content like images, text, and videos are typically classified as unstructured data.

attributes.definition: A characteristic of data sets related to the number of features or variables.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Refers to the number of attributes or features a data point has. High dimensionality can make data harder to analyze.

extractions.extraction_text: Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few.

attributes.definition: A characteristic of data where most values are zero or absent, meaning very few data points have actual values.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Describes data where most of the possible entries are empty or zero, like a large table with very few filled cells.

extractions.extraction_text: if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before.

attributes.example_text: An e-commerce record with millions of entries, but a user has only bought 10 books, making the data sparse.
attributes.purpose: Illustrate the concept of sparsity using a relatable e-commerce scenario.

attributes.definition: A characteristic of data sets where patterns can depend on the scale or granularity of the data.
attributes.simplified_explanation: The level of detail in data. The patterns you can see in data can change depending on how finely you look at it.

extractions.extraction_text: We want to talk about different type of the data set. We have the data matrix, document data, transaction data.

attributes.definition: Different categories of data sets including data matrix, document data, and transaction data.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data can be organized in various ways, such as in a table with numbers (data matrix), as text documents, or as records of transactions.

extractions.extraction_text: So data matrix look like this way. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes. Okay, they can become data metric. And then we allow them to do the ratio operation. All the value inside need to become the ratio data. So then right here, they need to be ratio data.

attributes.definition: A data set where each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes, and all values are ratio data.
attributes.simplified_explanation: A data matrix is like a spreadsheet where each row is an item and each column is a numerical characteristic, and these numbers can be used for calculations.

extractions.extraction_text: And the document data is a part that we were talking about later because before 2013, this is before 2013. Okay. And the people actually utilize document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector. Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data.

attributes.definition: Document data processed into a vector form by selecting important keywords and counting their occurrences, resulting in a term vector where each number is ratio data.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Before 2013, text documents were converted into numerical vectors by counting important words, making them usable for computer operations.

extractions.extraction_text: Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate.

attributes.definition: In computer science, vectors are used as a standard way to represent data for operations.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Vectors are a fundamental data structure in computer science that allow algorithms to perform calculations and manipulations on data.

text:
# LECTURE ANALYSIS: Types of Data Sets
## Video Segment: 110:58 - 114:58

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Sets". It lists two main categories: Structured Data Sets and Unstructured Data Sets. Structured data is described as a collection of data organized in certain formats, often in rows and columns, with a clear, predictable structure. Unstructured data is described as more complex and varied, usually derived from human-generated content like text, images, and videos.

[TRANSCRIPT - 110:58]
So the next one we want to talking about the data set. We have different type of data set. You might heard about the term called structured data or unstructured data. Structured data is you know exactly the meaning about the row and column. Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:36]
Luckily with this AI thing and right now text, image, video already can be converting into structured format, but you still need to be able to know once we convert, are they meaningful or not.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Characteristics of Data Sets". It lists three characteristics: Dimensionality (Curse of Dimensionality), Sparsity (Only presence counts), and Resolution (Patterns depend on the scale). A speech bubble says "Later" next to Sparsity.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:53]
So we have different kind of characteristic about our data dimension we mentioned before. Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few. Like what we say that if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse. So data are sparse. And sometimes in certain place, we will also talking about the resolution. And that part about sparsity, how to solving them, how to do the resolution, we will talking about later in some of the courses, some of them will be in classification, some of them will be in the text mining.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Types of Data Sets". It lists three types: Data Matrix, Document Data, and Transaction Data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 112:58]
We want to talk about different type of the data set. We have the data matrix, document data, transaction data. So data matrix look like this way. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes. Okay, they can become data metric. And then we allow them to do the ratio operation. All the value inside need to become the ratio data. So then right here, they need to be ratio data.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Matrix". It states: "If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes". A table shows "Book 1" to "Book 5" with columns for "Price", "Sells", "# Reviews", and "# Readers". The values are numeric.

[TRANSCRIPT - 114:48]
Okay. And the document data is a part that we were talking about later because before 2013, this is before 2013. Okay. And the people actually utilize document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector. Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data. But that is way we try to work in that before 2013. After 2013, how we try to do that? We will talking about that in the text mining part. So maybe three weeks later.
